results.title: Lessons in visual language 1-9
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Lessons in visual language”.
An award winning series of nine programs devised and narrated by Peter Thompson which explores the language of moving pictures. Each program takes a single idea and explores it in a way designed to inform, explain and stimulate discussion. 1. Framing (10 min) 2. Shot sizes and framing faults (9 min) 3. Third dimension (7 min) 4. Lenses and perspective’s (9 min) 5. Movement and the moving camera (11 min) 6. Orientation of the camera (11 min) 7. Image and screen (14 min) 8. Editing (10 min) 9. Rhythm (10 min).

results.title: Life in the trees
results.creator_credit: Richard Attenborough, John Sparks, Reiner Moritz Productions, Warner Bros Pictures and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode number 12 of Series “Life on Earth”.
David Attenborough examines the evolution of the primates. As well as looking at the better known members of the ape family - monkeys, gorillas and chimpanzees - it also looks at some of the lesser known cousins. This episode contains the memorable scene where David Attenborough meets a group of young mountain gorillas in Zaire.

results.title: The First forests
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Life on Earth”.
Part 3 of a series which traces the dramatic history of life on earth from its beginnings about 3,500 million years ago to the final emergence of man. In this episode David Attenborough discusses the evolution of plants from the first algae and moss-like plants that crept onto the land from the waters edge to the giant trees of todays forests, showing how they solved the two major problems of support and reproduction in the absence of water. The arrival of plants on land made it possible for animal life to live there as well and the evolution of the first plants and animals is inextricably linked. Also examines how plants grew taller, seeking light and how insects developed wings to reach their food sources. Microphotography is used to reveal unsuspected details of mosses, liverworts, ferns, cycads and conifers.

results.title: The Infinite Variety
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Life on Earth”.
David Attenborough examines the beginnings of life on earth. It took nearly 3,000 million years for life to evolve from the first primitive cells to a single creature such as a jellyfish, and these stages of evolution are traced.

results.title: The New morality
results.creator_credit: Mel Stuart, Richard Schickel and Time-Life Films
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “Life goes to the movies”.
Hosted by Henry Fonda, Shirley MacLaine and Liza Minnelli. Takes a look at the life and career of Marilyn Monroe as well as the movies of the sixties. Their language, sexuality and violence portraying a new morality unthinkable a deecade earlier. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: The Fifties
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Life goes to the movies”.
Examines the impact of television and the courts’ decisions to separate film exhibition from production and distribution in Hollywood’s film industry during the period up to the seventies. Shows a series of film clips exemplifying the 1950’s preoccupation with romantic love themes. Suitable for Upper Secondary School Students.

results.title: The Post-war era
results.creator_credit: Mel Stuart, Richard Schickel, Malcolm Leo, Jack Haley and Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Life goes to the movies”.
Hollywood turned to more mature themes in the late 1940s and early 1950s. Looks at “Film Noir” such as “Snake Pit” and “Lost Weekend”. Following McCarthyism hundreds of professionals were blacklisted. Another change of approach brought on a spate of monster films. Hosted by Henry Fonda. Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.
